text: This classic paper by William Wulf enumerates some principles of computer architecture design that might be interesting for anybody building their own machine <https://neilklingensmith.com/assets/papers/classicpapers/wulf-compilers-and-architecture.pdf>

text: It was only a matter of time that all the code from Github would be paired with OpenAI: <https://copilot.github.com>

attachments.title: GitHub Copilot · Your AI pair programmer
attachments.text: GitHub Copilot works alongside you directly in your editor, suggesting whole lines or entire functions for you.
attachments.fallback: GitHub Copilot: GitHub Copilot · Your AI pair programmer

elements.text: It was only a matter of time that all the code from Github would be paired with OpenAI:

text: Anyone here have preview access yet? This looks fascinating!

elements.text: Anyone here have preview access yet? This looks fascinating!

text:
I thought this is cool too, and then I saw this tweet. (linked from HN)
<https://twitter.com/mitsuhiko/status/1410886329924194309>
It's probably based on GPT-3, which means this will provide a most "popular" snippet, not necessarily a "correct" snippet. It is actually discovered that some of its codes use a questionable design (e.g. using a float for currency). I guess this is still usable for a boilerplate generator, but we shouldn't expect that much smartness in it. (which is a hard thing to do, because we tend to overestimate the ability of a black box.)

attachments.fallback: <https://twitter.com/mitsuhiko|@mitsuhiko>: I don't want to say anything but that's not the right license Mr Copilot. <https://pbs.twimg.com/tweet_video_thumb/E5R5lsfXoAQDRkE.jpg>
attachments.text: I don't want to say anything but that's not the right license Mr Copilot.
attachments.video_html: <video autoplay loop muted poster="https://pbs.twimg.com/tweet_video_thumb/E5R5lsfXoAQDRkE.jpg" width="1200" height="743"><source type="video/mp4" src="https://video.twimg.com/tweet_video/E5R5lsfXoAQDRkE.mp4"></video>

elements.text: I thought this is cool too, and then I saw this tweet. (linked from HN)

It's probably based on GPT-3, which means this will provide a most "popular" snippet, not necessarily a "correct" snippet. It is actually discovered that some of its codes use a questionable design (e.g. using a float for currency). I guess this is still usable for a boilerplate generator, but we shouldn't expect that much smartness in it. (which is a hard thing to do, because we tend to overestimate the ability of a black box.)

text: I just applied for preview access. But besides correctness, I'm curious what implications this has for software licensing. Is Copilot smart enough to detect the license that's in effect for wherever it's borrowing from?

elements.text: I just applied for preview access. But besides correctness, I'm curious what implications this has for software licensing. Is Copilot smart enough to detect the license that's in effect for wherever it's borrowing from?

text:
I think it inevitably raised the good old "does AI have authorship?" question.
This study suggests that it rarely verbatim copies the original code.
<https://docs.github.com/en/github/copilot/research-recitation>
Then someone strongly objected to GitHub using copyrighted materials for its training.
<https://thelig.ht/abandoning-github/>
The summary of this somewhat ongoing debate is found at HN:
<https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=27725407>

attachments.title: Research recitation - GitHub Docs
attachments.text: A first look at rote learning in GitHub Copilot suggestions.
